1.text: And Eliphaz the Themanite, answered, and said:

2.text: Will a wise man answer as if he were speaking in the wind, and fill his stomach with burning heat?

3.text: Thou reprovest him by words, who is not equal to thee, and thou speakest that which is not good for thee.

4.text: As much as is in thee, thou hast made void fear, and hast taken away prayers from before God.

5.text: For thy iniquity hath taught thy mouth, and thou imitatest the tongue of blasphemers.

6.text: Thy own mouth shall condemn thee, and not I: and thy own lips shall answer thee.

7.text: Art thou the first man that was born, or wast thou made before the hills ?

8.text: Hast thou heard Godâ€™s counsel, and shall his wisdom be inferior to thee?

9.text: What knowest thou that we are ignorant of? what dost thou understand that we know not?

10.text: There are with us also aged and ancient men, much elder than thy fathers.

11.text: Is it a great matter that God should comfort thee? but thy wicked words hinder this.

12.text: Why doth thy heart elevate thee, and why dost thou stare with thy eyes, as if they were thinking great things ?

13.text: Why doth thy spirit swell against God, to utter such words out of thy mouth ?

14.text: What is man that he should be without spot, and he that is born of a woman that he should appear just?

15.text: Behold among his saints none is unchangeable, and the heavens are not pure in his sight.

16.text: How much more is man abominable, and unprofitable, who drinketh iniquity like water?

17.text: I will shew thee, hear me : and I mill tell thee what I have seen.

18.text: Wise men confess and hide not their fathers.

19.text: To whom alone the earth was given, and no stranger hath passed among them.

20.text: The wicked man is proud all his days, and the number of the years of his tyranny is uncertain.

21.text: The sound of dread is always in his ears: and when there is peace, he always suspecteth treason.

22.text: He believeth not that he may return from darkness to light, looking round about for the sword on every side.

23.text: When he moveth himself to seek bread, he knoweth that the day of darkness is ready at his hand.

24.text: Tribulation shall terrify him, and distress shall surround him, as a king that is prepared for the battle.

25.text: For he hath stretched out his hand against God, and hath strengthened himself against the Almighty.

26.text: He hath run against him with his neck raised up, and is armed with a fat neck.

27.text: Fatness hath covered his face, and the fat hangeth down on his sides.

28.text: He hath dwelt in desolate cities, and in desert houses that are reduced into heaps.

29.text: He shall not be enriched, neither shall his substance continue, neither shall he push his root in the earth.

30.text: He shall not depart out of darkness: the flame shall dry up his branches, and he shall be taken away by the breath of his own month.

31.text: He shall not believe, being vainly deceived by error, that he may be redeemed with any price.

32.text: Before his days be full he shall perish: and his hands shall wither away.

33.text: He shall be blasted as a vine when its grapes are in the first flower, and as an olive tree that casteth its flower.

34.text: For the congregation of the hypocrite is barren, and fire shall devour their tabernacles, who love to take bribes.

35.text: He hath conceived sorrow, and hath brought forth iniquity, and his womb prepareth deceits.
